posts.post_content:
This card does what blue likes. Gaining advantage.
  
   
Counter a spell and you get 1 for 1 trade but then you get the countered card netting you a +1 advantage.
  
   
In the case of a burn spell you get still more advantage from turning it onto an opposing creature and icing it.

posts.post_content: To Donovan Fabian and Plantboy81 [Isochron Scepter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Isochron Scepter) works great with this card, but if you can lock down the board with [Rule of Law](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rule of Law) and [Ertai, Wizard Adept](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ertai, Wizard Adept) long enough to get this guy out it is pretty much game over. Very fun to do in multiplayer and listen to the other players groan.

posts.post_content:
Bring Guile and Dovescape into play. Play any non-creature spell; this will trigger Dovescape's ability and counter the spell, and bringing doves into play. Dovescape's countering ability will trigger Guile's ability. You can now play the same, previously triggered ability again without paying the mana cost, which will again be countered by Dovescape, bringing doves into play. This repeats forever, granting you an endless army of doves.   
  
All Props go to Tamanoa
posts.html:
Bring Guile and Dovescape into play. Play any non-creature spell; this will trigger Dovescape's ability and counter the spell, and bringing doves into play. Dovescape's countering ability will trigger Guile's ability. You can now play the same, previously triggered ability again without paying the mana cost, which will again be countered by Dovescape, bringing doves into play. This repeats forever, granting you an endless army of doves.

All Props go to Tamanoa

posts.post_content: Play encomp\*\*\*es Cast. Cast specifically refers to spells, but you "play" a land or a spell. You say lands are "played" because they almost always aren't "cast". They could come up with a specific word which means "play a land" but there's no need to.
posts.html:
Play encomp***es Cast. Cast specifically refers to spells, but you "play" a land or a spell. You say lands are "played" because they almost always aren't "cast". They could come up with a specific word which means "play a land" but there's no need to.
